description: This course describes how to configure and deploy a cloud with Microsoft System Center 2012 R2. It focuses on how to manage and administer a cloud environment, and it describes how you can configure and deploy the  cloud fabric. This course will help you to acquire the skills required to deploy and configure System Center 2012 R2 for Cloud and Datacenter hosting and management. In addition, how to use System Center Virtual Machine Manager, Service Manager, and Operations Manager to coordinate fabric monitoring is covered. If you are new to operating a private cloud, or have been managing one and want to update your skills, then this course will show you how.

WEBVTT

1

2

deploying a private cloud series.

5

I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.271 --> 00:00:21.394
In this episode, we'll continue to look at
how we can actually plan to deploy with

7
00:00:21.394 --> 00:00:24.030
systems that are virtual machine manager.

8
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:26.708
Back in studios today,
with us we have Mr. Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:26.708 --> 00:00:29.950

10

>> Thank you, always fun to be

11

we set up, manage, configure and

15

If you're just joining us and
have not watched it,

16

we just laid down some of
the navigational roadmap pointers there.

17
00:00:50.090 --> 00:00:53.480
What's the fabric,
what's the categories it's broken up into,

18

what's going on with that whole library
thing, what's in the settings area.

19
00:00:56.660 --> 00:00:59.970
Just some of those markers on the road
that help us to better understand

20
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:00.900
what we're doing.

21
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:04.080
Want to jump in and take a look at network
virtualization from an architecture

22
00:01:04.080 --> 00:01:07.970
perspective as we turn back to
our conversations on the console.

23
00:01:07.970 --> 00:01:09.812
Give you a little bit of the theory and

24
00:01:09.812 --> 00:01:13.420
the vocabulary around virtualization
of the networking stack.

25
00:01:13.420 --> 00:01:15.740
So we better understand some of
the things that are going on, in there.

26
00:01:15.740 --> 00:01:22.360
So we're gonna be talking about the idea
of how we look at network virtualization.

27
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:24.880
Specifically the idea of something,
the theory of something,

28
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:28.520
that is fundamental to any
virtualization conversation.

29
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:30.160
When we talk about traffic management.

30
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:32.080
Talk about network virtualization.

31
00:01:32.080 --> 00:01:35.300
We talked about the idea of encapsulation,
and specifically the idea of network

32
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:38.440
encapsulation is the idea
of taking traffic flows.

33
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:43.540
In this case probably our cloud traffic
flow, and we're gonna look at it, and

34
00:01:43.540 --> 00:01:47.020
isolate it, manage it,
and somehow manipulate it.

35
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:49.720
And package it up in such a way
that we can have it traverse.

36
00:01:49.720 --> 00:01:54.240
We can have it move through common
networks but still maintain its integrity,

37
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:58.670
its confidentiality, its availability
to the owner and to the carrier.

38
00:01:58.670 --> 00:02:01.560
Without commingling or in some way
getting modified, mixed up, and

39
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:06.620
or somehow being taken away
from us by other forces.

40
00:02:06.620 --> 00:02:09.958
Other entities, other tenants,
other flows in the system.

41
00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:13.570
So we're gonna look at how we segment or
segregate that traffic

42
00:02:13.570 --> 00:02:16.940
as it traverses across the physical
networks that are shared.

43
00:02:16.940 --> 00:02:19.850
Think of the internet,
think of the world wide web.

44
00:02:19.850 --> 00:02:23.230
Think of the exterior of your LAN,
in other words,

45
00:02:23.230 --> 00:02:25.280
generically we talk about that as the WAN.

46
00:02:25.280 --> 00:02:29.770
And as we move across the WAN to
complete communications where VMs and

47
00:02:29.770 --> 00:02:32.250
when VMs are distributed
across multiple hosts.

48
00:02:32.250 --> 00:02:34.590
If they're remote,
we may have geo-stretched or

49
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:37.270
geosynchronously distributed clustering.

50
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:40.720
So we may have hosts at different
locations that make up a data center

51
00:02:40.720 --> 00:02:46.820
cluster for us, or an SCVMM clustered
set of hosts, a host group.

52
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:51.209
We may have them all in one data center,
in one area geographically,

53
00:02:51.209 --> 00:02:53.260
in the same physical location.

54
00:02:53.260 --> 00:02:56.066
But they may be on different
portions of our network and

55
00:02:56.066 --> 00:02:59.640
we have to transit the LAN to be
able to complete communication.

56
00:02:59.640 --> 00:03:02.520
So either way, the idea of network
encapsulation is the idea of

57
00:03:02.520 --> 00:03:06.980
protecting that traffic as we move across
the physical cabling and the interfaces,

58
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:09.410
the switches, the routers, the firewalls.

59
00:03:09.410 --> 00:03:14.530
Whatever the case may be, and to allow
us to control and secure that traffic in

60
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:18.040
such a way that as we distribute it across
the multiple hosts in our host group.

61
00:03:18.040 --> 00:03:20.995
That we keep it isolated and
secured from all the other people,

62
00:03:20.995 --> 00:03:23.740
all the other tenants in our
multi-tenant environment.

63
00:03:23.740 --> 00:03:26.975
This becomes a very important
fundamental thought process for us.

64
00:03:26.975 --> 00:03:31.520
Software-defined networks help us to do
this and we're gonna define the various

65
00:03:31.520 --> 00:03:35.800
elements of the network through the
software interfaces in the SCVMM console.

66
00:03:35.800 --> 00:03:39.215
We've already hinted at that and
shown you some of those capabilities and

67
00:03:39.215 --> 00:03:40.600
explained the logical idea.

68
00:03:40.600 --> 00:03:44.477
At a high level of segmenting our
fabric into networking, into storage,

69
00:03:44.477 --> 00:03:48.980
and into the hosts area, the server's
area is what we call it, specifically.

70
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:52.490
And then looking at resources and
infrastructure on all three of those and

71
00:03:52.490 --> 00:03:55.730
using those components to
make up our communication and

72
00:03:55.730 --> 00:03:56.950
our ability to manage services.

73
00:03:56.950 --> 00:03:58.240
So we're gonna be looking at that.

74
00:03:58.240 --> 00:04:01.870
But software defining our networks
also gives us the ability to have

75
00:04:01.870 --> 00:04:06.710
the tenants bring in their
own IP addresses, IPv4, IPv6.

76
00:04:06.710 --> 00:04:08.770
The tenant may own their own addresses.

77
00:04:08.770 --> 00:04:12.090
And want to have their own address space,
and we can make that possible for

78
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:13.810
the tenants without conflicts.

79
00:04:13.810 --> 00:04:18.260
Meaning, if Cherokee was a tenant,
if I was a tenant, if we were both hosted.

80
00:04:18.260 --> 00:04:23.395
In the same general data center
environment, with shared infrastructure,

81
00:04:23.395 --> 00:04:29.404
in multi-tenant scenarios, we could both
use an IP Stack That was 192, 168, 0.

82
00:04:29.404 --> 00:04:33.400
Whatever the host IP's would be,
maybe one through 200.

83
00:04:33.400 --> 00:04:36.856
We could both claim those IP addresses
without any fear of conflict because we

84
00:04:36.856 --> 00:04:40.380
could isolate them and encapsulate them so
that they would not see each other.

85
00:04:40.380 --> 00:04:43.920
So this again is one of those things that
becomes very important for us to consider.

86
00:04:43.920 --> 00:04:48.340
Because, a lot of times, customers
do wanna use their own IP ranges.

87
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:51.590
And we often will be using private
IP ranges that are repeated,

88
00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:52.950
customer to customer, these days.

89
00:04:52.950 --> 00:04:53.630
This is very common.

90
00:04:53.630 --> 00:04:55.730
It has been for many, many years.

91
00:04:55.730 --> 00:04:56.790
For us to be doing that.

92
00:04:56.790 --> 00:05:00.770
And as a result, we wanna be aware of that
and just not only be sensitive to it, but

93
00:05:00.770 --> 00:05:04.670
also understand that we do
fully support IPv4 and IPv6.

94
00:05:04.670 --> 00:05:09.625
Which is a newer thought process
going from 32-bit to 128-bit in

95
00:05:09.625 --> 00:05:11.780
terms of the IP address block.

96
00:05:11.780 --> 00:05:15.628
And also as a result, quadrupling
the number of IP addresses available

97
00:05:15.628 --> 00:05:19.280
overall from billions into hundreds
of billions into many, many,

98
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:21.930
many, many, IP addresses, right, overall.

99
00:05:21.930 --> 00:05:24.080
So we're not worried
about that urban myth and

100
00:05:24.080 --> 00:05:25.820
legend of us running out of IP addresses.

101
00:05:25.820 --> 00:05:27.870
That has made the rounds for
so many years.

102
00:05:27.870 --> 00:05:30.870
It's amazing, cuz you hear, and
start to hear, about the fact that, hey,

103
00:05:30.870 --> 00:05:33.790
we're gonna run out of IP addresses,
and that's gonna be horrible.

104
00:05:33.790 --> 00:05:36.760
And that shouldn't happen, and we've
been hearing about that for a long time.

105
00:05:36.760 --> 00:05:39.199
But yet, at the same time,
we haven't run out of IPv4 addresses.

106
00:05:39.199 --> 00:05:39.837
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's

107
00:05:39.837 --> 00:05:43.170
amazing how things threaten to happen but
they never actually do.

108
00:05:43.170 --> 00:05:45.132
And we could keep going for
a long time, and

109
00:05:45.132 --> 00:05:48.030
probably never would run out of IP
addresses, to be honest with you.

110
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:50.787
But speaking of IP addresses,
we do have IPv4 and

111
00:05:50.787 --> 00:05:53.940
IPv6 inside through
software-defined networks, and

112
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:57.500
through encapsulation we keep
the IP address conflicts at bay.

113
00:05:57.500 --> 00:05:59.040
Don't have to worry about that.

114
00:05:59.040 --> 00:06:02.230
But when we move outside
the software-defined network out into

115
00:06:02.230 --> 00:06:06.620
the physical networks and out beyond
into things that are beyond our control.

116
00:06:06.620 --> 00:06:08.830
We must be using a gateway
in order to do so.

117
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:11.339
You know gateways commonly
use routers as firewalls,

118
00:06:11.339 --> 00:06:13.640
as border devices that
give us that flexibility.

119
00:06:13.640 --> 00:06:16.909
And we're gonna be able to bridge the
physical network with the virtual network

120
00:06:16.909 --> 00:06:18.060
by using a gateway device.

121
00:06:18.060 --> 00:06:19.350
Very important for us to do that.

122
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:23.480
>> Now those IP addresses cannot be
redundant within that physical address.

123
00:06:23.480 --> 00:06:27.690
>> On the physical plane those IP
addresses must be instantiated uniquely.

124
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:30.760
They cannot be redundant, as you said,
or we will have problems.

125
00:06:30.760 --> 00:06:34.127
There will be conflicts, because they
will see each other at some point in

126
00:06:34.127 --> 00:06:37.900
the pathway or in multiple pathways as
we cross traffic from here to there.

127
00:06:37.900 --> 00:06:41.320
And that will lead to a inability
to be able to transmit traffic.

128
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:43.000
We'll lose, through an IP conflict.

129
00:06:43.000 --> 00:06:44.480
We'll lose one or
more of those interfaces.

130
00:06:44.480 --> 00:06:45.630
So that's absolutely correct.

131
00:06:45.630 --> 00:06:49.290
Very good for us to remember that and
for us to be thinking about that.

132
00:06:49.290 --> 00:06:52.225
We assign two different
kinds of IP addresses.

133
00:06:52.225 --> 00:06:54.380
VMs are assigned two different
kinds of IP addresses.

134
00:06:54.380 --> 00:06:55.240
You may not know this, and

135
00:06:55.240 --> 00:06:58.040
most people don't realize this
when we talk about networking.

136
00:06:58.040 --> 00:07:00.886
And we set this up they say,
I have my IP address,

137
00:07:00.886 --> 00:07:03.481
I see it in my VM I go to
my virtual network card.

138
00:07:03.481 --> 00:07:06.867
And I can pull it up and I do an IP
config or the equivalent in Linux,

139
00:07:06.867 --> 00:07:09.340
IF config or
whatever it is that you're doing.

140
00:07:09.340 --> 00:07:11.900
Cuz the Mac has that whole crazy thing
that nobody else understands and

141
00:07:11.900 --> 00:07:14.430
they do their own thing, but
however you do it, right?

142
00:07:14.430 --> 00:07:19.100
We pull up the IP address configuration
and we see we have an IP address.

143
00:07:19.100 --> 00:07:22.120
Look, I have 192.168.0.5, that's me.

144
00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:23.080
Yeah, absolutely, you have that.

145
00:07:23.080 --> 00:07:24.820
We call that a customer address.

146
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:25.630
That's what we call it.

147
00:07:25.630 --> 00:07:29.260
We actually call it in our stack a CA,
customer address.

148
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:32.900
This is the IP visible within the virtual
machine network, an IP address range that

149
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:36.300
is defined by the tenant traditionally,
so it's controlled by them.

150
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:38.810
This allows us to enable and
permit communication.

151
00:07:38.810 --> 00:07:44.424
Between the VMs on premises within our
infrastructure stack and from the physical

152
00:07:44.424 --> 00:07:49.160
out to the cloud space using a VPN
if necessary to move back and forth.

153
00:07:49.160 --> 00:07:52.235
But the customer address is the one
that shows up in the virtual machine and

154
00:07:52.235 --> 00:07:55.390
the virtual network that we could see and
the tenant interacts with.

155
00:07:55.390 --> 00:07:58.970
We also have a secondary, a second
address, not secondary, I was gonna say.

156
00:07:58.970 --> 00:08:01.777
Secondary comes in with VLANs and
private VLANs as we stack them,

157
00:08:01.777 --> 00:08:03.110
we'll talk about that.

158
00:08:03.110 --> 00:08:06.405
But rather, a second address called
the Provider Address, the PA.

159
00:08:06.405 --> 00:08:09.912
As opposed to the customer address,
the CA, two distinct addresses,

160
00:08:09.912 --> 00:08:13.690
provider address is based on
the physical network infrastructure.

161
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:17.421
And this is used only on the physical
network as we were talking about,

162
00:08:17.421 --> 00:08:18.760
not presented to the VM.

163
00:08:18.760 --> 00:08:21.440
VM doesn't see it,
doesn't have knowledge of it directly.

164
00:08:21.440 --> 00:08:24.060
But rather we use it to
transfer the number traffic

165
00:08:24.060 --> 00:08:27.948
between devices that participate
in the network virtualization.

166
00:08:27.948 --> 00:08:32.460
And through Hyper-V in the abstraction
of and the creation of those networks.

167
00:08:32.460 --> 00:08:35.420
And so the provider address is
used to move traffic back and

168
00:08:35.420 --> 00:08:39.900
forth between the host and
the VM itself, moving it back and forth.

169
00:08:39.900 --> 00:08:43.380
But it's not exposed to the VM cuz it's
controlled at the host level rather than

170
00:08:43.380 --> 00:08:47.300
used by the VM inside the virtual
network to be able to move traffic and

171
00:08:47.300 --> 00:08:50.230
expose to that particular machines.

172
00:08:50.230 --> 00:08:53.260

00:02:53.890 --> 00:02:56.450

78
00:04:05.960 --> 00:04:09.900

00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:11.090
OS profile, and

00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:15.170

81
00:04:15.170 --> 00:04:17.327
So that's what we're doing,

82
00:04:17.327 --> 00:04:21.310

00:04:31.395 --> 00:04:35.445

00:04:35.445 --> 00:04:38.465
So we would come down here,

00:04:38.465 --> 00:04:43.330
We would choose the appropriate OS

00:04:43.330 --> 00:04:47.754

91
00:04:47.754 --> 00:04:51.692
We then walk through and
specify things like computer name,

92
00:04:51.692 --> 00:04:54.840

93
00:04:54.840 --> 00:04:59.040

94
00:04:59.040 --> 00:05:02.545
Our time zones, all the standard

95
00:05:02.545 --> 00:05:04.585

00:05:07.461 --> 00:05:13.235

Are we in a work group,

00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:57.810

Notice, by the way,

00:22:54.724 --> 00:22:57.882

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.470

2

4

>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
Microsoft MCSE Private Cloud Series.

5
00:00:16.144 --> 00:00:18.218
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.218 --> 00:00:21.490
Today back in studio we have Mr.
Adam Gordan.

7
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:23.309
Thank you for joining us today Adam.

8
00:00:23.309 --> 00:00:24.970
>> Hello.

9
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:25.470
>> Hello.
>> Hello.

10
00:00:25.470 --> 00:00:30.490

around showing you different aspects of

11
00:00:30.490 --> 00:00:33.810

00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:37.010

13

00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:44.880

to deal with event notifications, alert

15
00:00:44.880 --> 00:00:48.970

run as profiles and deal with that.

16
00:00:48.970 --> 00:00:53.010

talk about distributed applications.

17
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:56.530
How we can diagram out or
essentially create a reference for

then monitor against that stack.

19
00:00:59.910 --> 00:01:02.390
So, we're gonna start off in
the console take a look here,

20
00:01:02.390 --> 00:01:04.190

00:01:04.190 --> 00:01:08.240
Over here in the left wing of

I've already gone ahead and

00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:13.680

24
00:01:13.680 --> 00:01:15.170
We'll then go ahead and go back and

25
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:19.210

Distributed Application Wizard.

00:01:47.710 --> 00:01:49.240

35
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:51.080
I've an object called Server and

00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:53.930
I've added a specific instance
of a Window Server here.

00:01:53.930 --> 00:01:58.090
And when I hover, which you'll notice is,

00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:01.600

But I get a pop out hover, indicates

00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:14.880
But it's only there for about ten seconds.

43
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:15.490
It's hard to read.

00:02:15.490 --> 00:02:19.620
So, if you highlight that,
all that information shows up down here in

00:02:19.620 --> 00:02:24.320

the display name, principal name, DNS,

46
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:29.520

00:02:29.520 --> 00:02:31.320
The network name,

00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:34.880
we have the Active Directory

49
00:02:34.880 --> 00:02:40.450

50
00:02:40.450 --> 00:02:43.820
We have quite a bit of information
if it is a virtual machine.

51
00:02:43.820 --> 00:02:45.840
We can tell that it's a virtual machine.

52
00:02:45.840 --> 00:02:47.460
All that stuff would be available to us.

53
00:02:47.460 --> 00:02:49.380
So all of that is here.

00:02:49.380 --> 00:02:52.640

00:03:04.790 --> 00:03:05.572

>> [LAUGH]

00:03:05.572 --> 00:03:06.302

>> Perhaps next time when I'm

>> So you'll see Alert View,

00:03:25.790 --> 00:03:29.880
any of these stages would allow to be able
to click an access the information for

00:03:29.880 --> 00:03:31.520
that, so you'll see that.

00:03:31.520 --> 00:03:35.700
We have our instance properties, Health

00:03:35.700 --> 00:03:38.840
the importance of the ops manager shelf,
you could see that or

00:03:38.840 --> 00:03:40.250

00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:49.670
Now we could do the same

00:03:49.670 --> 00:03:52.920
then out far on the right we have

76
00:03:52.920 --> 00:03:58.020
We could use this information, or

00:03:58.020 --> 00:04:02.610
Right down here for instance to be

00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:06.800
ping the computer perhaps to
a remote desktop out to it, right?

79
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:08.710
So there's all this different
stuff that we could do.

80
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:12.950
If we use one of these tasks you'll notice

00:04:12.950 --> 00:04:16.060

00:04:16.060 --> 00:04:17.030

00:04:17.030 --> 00:04:18.160
And I could do that, so

00:04:18.160 --> 00:04:20.910

00:04:20.910 --> 00:04:23.940

00:04:25.970 --> 00:04:27.020

00:04:30.560 --> 00:04:33.480

00:04:33.480 --> 00:04:35.920

00:04:35.920 --> 00:04:37.260

00:05:01.890 --> 00:05:03.900

00:05:03.900 --> 00:05:05.510
I can see whatever is not being monitored.

00:05:05.510 --> 00:05:07.840

00:05:07.840 --> 00:05:10.400

00:05:10.400 --> 00:05:12.160

00:05:12.160 --> 00:05:15.200

00:05:15.200 --> 00:05:17.670

00:05:17.670 --> 00:05:20.170
May be a service or
something like that, and

00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:22.980

00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:27.015
I can refresh in any area,

bring me back in updating it.

00:05:29.970 --> 00:05:32.890

00:05:32.890 --> 00:05:35.170

00:05:35.170 --> 00:05:39.840
So the application, or distribute

00:05:39.840 --> 00:05:43.460

00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:48.030
Here you can see when

00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:55.140
As we use our distributed application

00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:57.920
this is the one that I

00:05:57.920 --> 00:06:00.380

That once it's there and created we then

That's what I was doing just now and

00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:15.960

00:06:17.850 --> 00:06:20.910

00:06:20.910 --> 00:06:23.400

00:06:23.400 --> 00:06:25.810
We could see the state in

131

00:06:28.860 --> 00:06:32.390
Is our APM or application
performance monitoring taking place,

I'm not seeing that.

But in the real world,

476
00:21:45.790 --> 00:21:49.870
if I was actually doing this, then what

477
00:21:49.870 --> 00:21:53.990
I'd be able to see the tracking of all
that information and be able to interact

478
00:21:53.990 --> 00:21:56.590
with it against the real site that
I've setup the monitoring for.

479
00:21:56.590 --> 00:22:01.400
I'm just using essentially a proxy site to
show you the idea of starting the monitor

480
00:22:01.400 --> 00:22:03.180
just so you could see what
the capture would look like.

481
00:22:03.180 --> 00:22:05.240
But you'll see,
if we launch it from outside,

00:22:05.240 --> 00:22:08.280
essentially done the same way,
takes us back to the same place.

483
00:22:08.280 --> 00:22:11.655
We run the capture, and then we're able to
view the results when we're done, right?

484
00:22:11.655 --> 00:22:13.875
So that's what we just
wanted to show you quickly.

485
00:22:13.875 --> 00:22:17.921
Just let me not save our changes there,
and just come back out to our default,

486
00:22:17.921 --> 00:22:19.614
or rather our standard viewer.

487
00:22:19.614 --> 00:22:20.735
We see our web app monitor.

488
00:22:20.735 --> 00:22:22.585
And we could just stack these monitors up,

489
00:22:22.585 --> 00:22:26.455

sense for you so that you can see them.

490
00:22:26.455 --> 00:22:29.435
And then we're able to do our
end to end service monitoring.

491
00:22:29.435 --> 00:22:33.280
But in this particular case, we're

00:22:33.280 --> 00:22:36.530

set up a web app monitor.

And to then look at the interaction with

and test their response time, and all

495
00:22:43.710 --> 00:22:46.525
>> There's a lot of different monitoring
capabilities within this particular

496
00:22:46.525 --> 00:22:48.755
utility, so thank you for

497
00:22:48.755 --> 00:22:52.515

498
00:22:52.515 --> 00:22:55.205

00:22:57.126 --> 00:22:58.765

topics.title: Deploying and Configuring Access to a Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Adam begin discussing different monitoring tools available for your cloud infrastructure. Adam Explains System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) and shows a layout describing SCOM components. Adam implores individuals to leverage tools such as Fabric Health dashboard/ diagram view, Team Foundation Server (TFS), web consoles, System Center Advisor, Unix/Linux monitoring and more!
episodes.title: Monitoring Cloud Infrastructure

69

We have the ability to be able
to use another product, called

00:04:35.590 --> 00:04:39.250

00:04:39.250 --> 00:04:42.930
So System Center Advisor's just

00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:46.910

over the Internet, over

00:04:54.630 --> 00:04:58.330

00:04:58.330 --> 00:04:59.960
So all these moving parts and

pieces along with the app controller

00:05:03.760 --> 00:05:08.320
which is gonna provide our service or

00:05:08.320 --> 00:05:11.574

96
00:05:11.574 --> 00:05:15.566
across public and private clouds by being

97
00:05:15.566 --> 00:05:18.460
And we've talked about all these
different moving parts and pieces.

98
00:05:18.460 --> 00:05:22.300
Just high level reminding you of what
is in the System Center Suite as we

99
00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:22.890

100
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:25.910
But we're gonna drill down and

00:05:25.910 --> 00:05:28.880
on the System Center Ops Manager product.

00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:33.220
Take a look at what it does and give you
over our conversations in this episode and

103
00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:36.520
in the upcoming episodes that we're

00:05:36.520 --> 00:05:39.881
Really helps for a good idea of

00:05:39.881 --> 00:05:43.044
in this case,
data center based cloud monitoring, and

00:05:43.044 --> 00:05:46.437
how we use a product like SCOM

00:05:46.437 --> 00:05:49.502
If you wanna join me over here for

So getting started with
System Center 2012 Ops Manager,

00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:17.480
So just general overview,

that's why I'm not too concerned

00:06:20.190 --> 00:06:22.680
But you'll see that we

00:06:22.680 --> 00:06:24.938
some basic information about what's new.

00:06:24.938 --> 00:06:27.200
We're gonna take a look at

us just about the architecture.

00:06:36.067 --> 00:06:37.895

00:06:37.895 --> 00:06:40.125

00:07:18.450 --> 00:07:21.420

00:07:38.395 --> 00:07:41.190

00:07:41.190 --> 00:07:43.985

00:07:43.985 --> 00:07:47.696

150
00:07:47.696 --> 00:07:49.105
APM allows us to go in and

00:07:49.105 --> 00:07:54.039

00:07:54.039 --> 00:07:59.042
but link back to our organization either

00:07:59.042 --> 00:08:03.834

00:08:03.834 --> 00:08:07.550
JEE, or Java EE,
the Java Enterprise Edition platform.

155
00:08:07.550 --> 00:08:12.233
So we can monitor both Windows-based and

157
00:08:16.677 --> 00:08:20.950
Because although your Microsoft solution,
Microsoft centric would like to think

158
00:08:20.950 --> 00:08:24.760
that the majority of our monitoring
is gonna focus on Microsoft products.

159
00:08:24.760 --> 00:08:25.740
We have to be realistic and

160
00:08:25.740 --> 00:08:30.540
understand that while Microsoft does
have very large share of that market,

161
00:08:30.540 --> 00:08:34.010
there are many other solutions for web
services that are not Microsoft-centric.

162
00:08:34.010 --> 00:08:36.920
We'd be fooling ourselves if we
don't figure out that we have

163
00:08:36.920 --> 00:08:41.900
to monitor those equally alongside of all
the other stuff we do in our data center.

164
00:08:41.900 --> 00:08:42.860
And this new feature,

165
00:08:42.860 --> 00:08:46.610
this ability in 12 R2 gives us that
capability to be able to do that.

166
00:08:46.610 --> 00:08:48.390
So be aware of that, performance and

167
00:08:48.390 --> 00:08:52.260
availability monitoring, both on the
server side and the client side, with APM.

168
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:56.400
So we get a complete picture of what's
going on on the server in the web form or

169
00:08:56.400 --> 00:09:00.200
wherever it is in the data center
with regards to our resources,

170
00:09:00.200 --> 00:09:04.650
our ability to access databases, present
information, whatever that may be, but

171
00:09:04.650 --> 00:09:05.940
also the client side experience.

172
00:09:05.940 --> 00:09:09.250
How is the client being able to
communicate with that web server?

173
00:09:09.250 --> 00:09:10.320
How responsive is it?

174
00:09:10.320 --> 00:09:11.730
Is there a lot of latency?

175
00:09:11.730 --> 00:09:14.276
How quickly are we able
to do what we need to do?

176
00:09:14.276 --> 00:09:17.624
And we can do synthetic transaction
monitoring, we can look at all sorts of

177
00:09:17.624 --> 00:09:20.350
different ways of doing this,
and we have that capability.

178
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:24.550
So we have two new web consoles that
also provide deep introspection and

179
00:09:24.550 --> 00:09:26.690
monitoring capabilities in this area.

180
00:09:26.690 --> 00:09:27.750
Root cause analysis and

181
00:09:27.750 --> 00:09:30.840
reporting on exception events
will be what we get out of those.

182
00:09:30.840 --> 00:09:33.720
So we'll be taking a look at some of
those and talking about those as we go.

183
00:09:33.720 --> 00:09:36.820
We also have Fabric Monitoring, as you
can see on the screen behind you here,

184
00:09:38.110 --> 00:09:40.720
behind me I should say, but
on the screen right there.

185
00:09:40.720 --> 00:09:43.130
The Fabric Health Dashboard,
this allows us to go in and

186
00:09:43.130 --> 00:09:45.130

187
00:09:45.130 --> 00:09:47.830
This is one of the key things
we are also gonna be able to do.

188
00:09:47.830 --> 00:09:51.550
And we're linking this back to the idea

all management servers
